Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Identification and Analysis of Key Dynamics Required for Sustainable Operations of Texas Food Banks after Hurricane Disasters

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) award will provide support for data collection efforts at the Central Texas Food Bank in Austin, Texas and the Houston Food Bank in Houston, Texas in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey. Food banks are a critical support network for populations at-risk for hunger and malnutrition. Their operations include wholesaling of surplus food from stores and farms, procuring and warehousing bulk donations, and distribution of food and household goods to a variety of charitable agencies. Most large urban food banks provide meals for hundreds of thousands of people each week. In addition to their normal operations, many food banks serve as disaster-relief agencies by providing food and supplies to displaced residents. When a large food bank is itself seriously impacted by a large-scale disaster, deliveries to the food bank and distribution from the food bank to relief organizations must be rerouted to neighboring food banks capable of serving the affected population. When Hurricane Harvey disabled the Houston Food Bank, the largest Feeding America food bank in the US, the Central Texas Food Bank in Austin and the San Antonio Food Bank operated well past full capacity under challenging circumstances to take up the slack. These food banks currently operate as an informal network with no specific mechanisms or practices in place to guide a regional response to a disaster of this magnitude.

The PI and his team of graduate and undergraduate students will collect data on surge capacity, transient operating conditions, and performance at these neighboring food banks as they worked to support the residents of southeastern Texas affected by the hurricane. The research objectives are to: (1) characterize the key logistic obstacles and bottlenecks when a major food bank is disrupted; (2) identify staff capacity and limitations (including both paid and volunteer staff) at neighboring food banks; (3) determine first aid products needed by displaced individuals; and (4) identify what partnerships/agreements (both formal and informal) between food banks were in place and utilized during these operations. This project will enable study of how regional coordination among food banks can be improved to deliver needed food and basic necessities to communities affected by large scale disasters that disrupt a critical element of the recovery effort.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this RAPID NSF proposal was to advance the operational capabilities of food banks when their service region has the potential or it is affected by natural disasters such as Hurricane Harvey. The main objective of the proposed research work was to compile and analyze time sensitive operational data from the Central Texas Food Bank in Austin TX and the Houston Food Bank in Houston TX after hurricane Harvey. The research team collected data on surge capacity, transient operating conditions, and performance at these neighboring food banks as they worked to support the residents of southeastern Texas affected by the hurricane. The research objectives were to: (1) characterize the key logistic obstacles and bottlenecks when a major food bank is disrupted; (2) identify staff capacity and limitations (including both paid and volunteer staff) at neighboring food banks; (3) determine first aid products needed by displaced individuals; and (4) identify what partnerships/agreements (both formal and informal) between food banks were in place and utilized during these operations. The data collected is vital for the future development of standard operational procedures that will specify the activities that food banks and their network must perform to better prepare for the arrival of a natural disaster. The data will also allow food banks to improve their operations during the recovery phase of the natural disaster.

This project acquired, cleaned, and analyzed data that will serve to advance the operational capabilities of food banks when their service region has the potential or is affected by natural disasters. The data collected and future models are likely to produce a broader understanding the role of volunteers, donations, and communication in the food bank network and delivery services. The analysis of the key dynamics required for sustainable operations of Texas food banks is novel within the engineering field. The insights obtained from the research are expected to help in the development and implementation of preparation and mitigation protocols for hurricane future events.

Classified as a Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI), Texas State University plays an important role in the training of future Hispanic scientists and engineers in Texas and the United States. This research presented unique opportunities that increased the participation of underrepresented groups in engineering and enabled interdisciplinary education for undergraduate and graduate students.

This project also improved current course offering through the development of pedagogical case studies. The PI developed two case studies for undergraduate instruction in industrial engineering. He is currently offering courses in engineering statistics and operations research at Texas State University. These case studies describe a contextual scenario and then ask the students to apply the concepts learned in class to complete open ended activities. Case Study 1 was designed for IE 3320 Engineering Statistics and involves data analysis and forecast models. Case Study 2 was designed for IE 3340 Operations Research and involves the formulation of linear, integer, and mixed integer programming models for food banks' resource allocation by considering multiple uncertainty factors. Based on the PI's experience, case studies exercises can improve students' understanding of the material and their ability to solve problems.
